description: Basic ideas of probability and statistics. Statistical methods especially suited for the social, behavioral and biological sciences. Continuation of STAT 111. Focus on multiple regression, analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, and regression diagnostics. Selected topics in the generalized linear modeling including binomial and Poisson regression. Conceptual foundations are addressed as well as hands-on use for data analysis.
name: INTRODUCTORY STATISTICS

values.comments:
This course, a continuation of STAT 111, covers basic ideas of probability and statistics and statistical methods for the behavioral sciences, especially psychology, with emphasis on regression, analysis of variance, experimental design, and analysis of covariance. 

“Classes like this make you question and critically evaluate what you read and hear in the news and push you to see the world in a different way,” one student said. A focus on applications to everyday life kept the class engaging, but according to one student, the course was “poorly structured to allow most effective conveyance of pertinent material and subject matter.” 

Many students agreed that “Professor Wainer is a talented lecturer who not only has background knowledge of statistics, but shows great enthusiasm in its application to our everyday lives.” 

The class was “geared for learning’s sake,” according to one student, so students could resubmit some homework assignments and their midterms. However, homework was often “frustrating” and included a lot of busy work.
